unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Finding the Standard Deviation of $X-Y$
question_text:
A random variable $X$ has a mean of $40$ and standard deviation of $7$. A random variable $Y$ has a mean of $30$ and a standard deviation of $5$.
If $X$ and $Y$ are independent, approximately what is the standard deviation of $X-Y$?
solution:
The first step in finding the differences in the standard deviation is to find the variance. Remember that variances always add and never subtract:

$${ \sigma }_{ X-Y }^{ 2 }={ \sigma }_{ x }^{ 2 }+{ \sigma }_{ Y }^{ 2 }$$

$$=({ 7) }^{ 2 }+({ 5 })^{ 2 }$$

$$=74$$

The second step is to square root the variance:

$$\sqrt { 74 }=8.60$$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect as this is the variance.

Choice 'B' is incorrect as the two standard deviations were just added together.

Choice 'D' is incorrect as this is the average of the two standard deviations.

Choice 'E' is incorrect as the standard deviations were subtracted.
